notes.note_text:
Parent report:
- Caregiver reported ongoing concerns about clarity of speech, especially with unfamiliar listeners. Noted that child is “chatty” but often hard to understand beyond family. No major changes since initial evaluation.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned to the therapy room with brief hesitation, then engaged well with play-based activities. Required occasional redirection from preferred toys but responded to visual schedules and clear expectations. Participated in turn-taking games with support.

Goals / session focus:
1. Establish production of /k/ in isolation and simple syllables (CV)
- At baseline, child consistently fronted /k/ to /t/ in spontaneous speech (e.g., “tat” for “cat”).
- With direct modeling and use of a “back sound” cue (touching throat, visual of tongue placement), child produced /k/ in isolation inconsistently. Able to achieve a clear /k/ in approximately half of imitated attempts with maximal verbal and visual cueing.
- Briefly trialed /k/ in CV syllables (e.g., “koo,” “kah”); accuracy was low and required simultaneous production with clinician.

2. Initial /f/ at syllable and word level (imitation)
- Child often substituted /p/ for /f/ in conversation (e.g., “pish” for “fish”).
- In structured imitation tasks, able to approximate /f/ with strong airflow when given “bite your lip and blow” cue and visual model. Accuracy higher in isolation than in syllables.
- At word level (e.g., “fun,” “feet,” “fish”), productions were mostly stopped to /p/ even with cues; a few accurate productions emerged with very slow rate and repeated modeling.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Child produced /s/ in isolation with inconsistent airflow; some productions were lateral or reduced to /t/.
- With mirror work and “snake sound” cue, able to produce a clearer /s/ intermittently, but needed ongoing reminders to keep tongue behind teeth.
- Did not yet move into word-level /s/ this session due to focus on establishing consistent sound.

4. Functional communication / phrase length (observation only)
- During play, child used mostly 3–4 word utterances (e.g., “I want that one,” “my turn now”), but speech was often reduced in clarity due to sound errors and fast rate.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to target /k/ and /f/ in isolation and simple syllables with maximal support next session.
- Introduce more structured CV and VC practice for /k/ and /f/ as tolerated.
- Encourage caregiver to model slow, clear productions of words with /k/ and /f/ in daily routines without asking child to repeat every time (e.g., “keys,” “cup,” “fish,” “food”).
- Plan to gather additional baseline data on /s/ blends in upcoming sessions once single sound /s/ stabilizes.

Parent report:
- Caregiver shared that child is starting junior kindergarten in the fall and wants them to be easier for peers to understand. No notable changes in speech since last visit, though caregiver thinks /k/ is “a tiny bit better” in some practiced words.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child separated from caregiver more smoothly today and joined the therapist at the table with minimal prompting. Demonstrated good participation in turn-based games and was motivated by stickers and a simple board game. Attention to task was generally good with brief movement breaks.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in CV and VC syllables (imitation)
- Building on prior isolation work, child practiced /k/ in CV (e.g., “koo, kah, kee”) and VC (e.g., “ak, ik”).
- With verbal cueing (“back sound”) and visual model, accuracy improved compared to last session. Child produced more consistent /k/ at the start and end of syllables with moderate cueing rather than maximal.
- Noted some spontaneous self-correction attempts when fronting to /t/ (e.g., said “too,” paused, then attempted “koo” with support).

2. Initial /k/ at word level (imitation)
- Introduced simple /k/ initial words (e.g., “key, cow, car, cat”).
- Child was able to imitate several words with a recognizable /k/ when given a slowed model and occasional tactile cue (light touch to throat/under chin to cue “back” sound).
- Errors included fronting to /t/ or omitting the initial consonant; however, accurate productions were more frequent than at baseline, indicating emerging word-level skills.

3. Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued work on /f/ in isolation with “bite your lip and blow” cue. Child showed clearer, more consistent airflow compared to previous session.
- Practiced CV syllables (“foo, faa, fee”); able to maintain /f/ in initial position in about half of imitated attempts with moderate cueing.
- Word-level practice remained challenging, with frequent /p/ substitutions, but there were a few clearer approximations when rate was slowed and visual attention to the clinician’s mouth was encouraged.

4. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Child showed slightly more consistent /s/ in isolation with visual feedback in the mirror.
- Trialed /s/ in CV combinations (e.g., “soo, see”). Productions varied between accurate /s/, /sh/, and /t/. Verbal reminders to “keep tongue behind teeth” were somewhat helpful, but the sound is still emerging.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /k/ at the word level in imitation; if consistency continues to improve, consider introducing a small set of functional /k/ words for use in simple phrases.
- Maintain focus on /f/ in isolation and syllables; delay heavy word-level demands until accuracy is more stable.
- Continue shaping /s/ in isolation with mirror work and airflow cues.
- Caregiver encouraged to play short “sound games” at home, focusing on making long /k/ and /f/ sounds together in a playful way rather than drilling words.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported noticing clearer /k/ in a few familiar words at home (e.g., “car,” “cookie”) when the child is reminded. They feel others still have difficulty understanding the child in conversation. No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered session happily and was eager to show a toy car from home. Participated well in both floor play and table tasks. Needed occasional prompts to stay seated during drill activities, but returned to tasks with gentle reminders.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ at word level (imitation → supported spontaneous)
- Practiced a set of familiar /k/ words (“car, cat, key, cookie, coat”) using pictures and toy items.
- Child imitated /k/ initial words with noticeably improved accuracy compared to last week, often needing only a brief visual model and occasional verbal cue.
- Began to use some /k/ words spontaneously in structured play (e.g., saying “car go” while moving the toy car), though consistency in spontaneous use is still emerging.

2. Initial /k/ in 2–3 word phrases (imitation)
- Introduced short carrier phrases (e.g., “my car,” “big cat,” “go car”) at the imitated phrase level.
- With moderate cueing for the initial /k/, child produced several phrases with a clear /k/ in at least one of multiple trials. Some blends of /t/ and /k/ were observed, but overall clarity was better than at the single-word level during earlier sessions.

3. Initial /f/ at word level (imitation)
- Moved into imitated word-level practice for /f/ (“fish, fun, feet, five”) while continuing to use the “bite lip and blow” cue.
- Compared to previous sessions, child demonstrated a more stable /f/ in isolation and was able to carry this over to word-initial position in a meaningful number of attempts.
- Errors still included /p/ substitutions, especially when speech rate increased, but there were clear, accurate productions in structured practice.

4. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued shaping /s/ with mirror feedback. Child produced a few sustained, fairly accurate /s/ sounds with verbal reminders.
- CV syllables (e.g., “see, soo”) remained inconsistent, with frequent shifts to /sh/ or /t/. However, child showed better awareness of tongue placement and was able to correct with immediate modeling.

Plan / recommendations:
- Given progress, continue to expand /k/ practice at the phrase level with strong visual supports and play-based routines.
- Maintain /f/ at the imitated word level, aiming for more consistent accuracy before moving to phrases.
- Continue to focus on establishing a reliable /s/ sound in isolation; defer /s/ word-level goals until production is more stable.
- Caregiver encouraged to model short phrases with target /k/ words at home (e.g., “my car,” “big cookie”) and praise any clear /k/ attempts.

Parent report:
- Caregiver shared that child is now sometimes correcting themselves on /k/ at home (e.g., “tat—cat!”). They feel /f/ is still hard to hear in words. No new medical or developmental concerns reported.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly into the therapy room and engaged quickly with a car and animal play set. Attention was generally good; needed brief breaks between structured drill sets. Demonstrated good rapport with clinician and responded well to visual timers.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in 2–3 word phrases (imitation → reduced cues)
- Continued practice of phrases such as “my car,” “go car,” “big cat,” “cookie please.”
- Compared to last week, child required fewer prompts to produce /k/ accurately within phrases. Often a single model or reminder (“back sound”) was sufficient.
- Accuracy in imitated phrases was noticeably higher, and there were more spontaneous attempts during play (e.g., “my car” without a model), though still not fully consistent.

2. Initial /k/ in simple sentences (imitation)
- Introduced short sentences (e.g., “The car is big,” “I see a cat”) at the imitated level.
- With moderate cueing, child produced /k/ clearly in many attempts, though accuracy decreased as sentence length increased. Some omissions and fronting persisted, but the child was able to repair after a model.

3. Initial /f/ at word level and emerging phrases
- Practiced /f/ initial words (“fish, fun, four, feet”) using picture cards and a fishing game.
- Accuracy in imitated words improved from prior sessions, with more consistent /f/ rather than /p/ when rate was controlled and child watched the clinician’s mouth.
- Trialed short phrases (e.g., “four fish,” “fun food”) with mixed success. Child could sometimes maintain /f/ at the start of the first word but often reverted to /p/ in connected speech.

4. /s/ in isolation and initial word probes
- Continued isolation practice for /s/ using mirror and “long snake sound” cue. Child showed better control of airflow and tongue placement.
- Briefly probed initial /s/ words (e.g., “sun, sock, soup”) at the imitated level. Productions were variable, including /t/, /sh/, and some approximations of /s/. This will remain a secondary focus while /k/ and /f/ continue to develop.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /k/ at the phrase and short sentence levels, gradually fading cues as tolerated.
- Maintain /f/ at the word level while gently increasing phrase-level opportunities in structured play.
- Keep /s/ primarily at isolation with occasional word-level probes to monitor readiness.
- Caregiver encouraged to model and emphasize /f/ words during daily routines (e.g., “feet, food, fun”) and to praise child’s attempts, without overcorrecting.

Parent report:
- Caregiver noted that family members are understanding the child a bit more when they talk about cars and cookies, but strangers still have difficulty. They reported hearing a few clearer /f/ words like “four” during playtime.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child was cheerful on arrival and quickly engaged with a picture book and small figurines. Maintained attention for longer drill sets than previous weeks, with minimal need for redirection. Demonstrated good turn-taking and followed simple game rules with support.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in short sentences and structured play (imitation → emerging spontaneous)
- Continued work on short sentences with /k/ words (e.g., “The car is fast,” “I see a cat,” “My cookie is big”).
- Child showed more consistent accuracy in imitated sentences and required fewer explicit cues for /k/. Often produced /k/ correctly after a single model.
- During car and animal play, child spontaneously produced some /k/ words and short phrases (e.g., “big car,” “my cat”) with clearer /k/ than previously noted, though not yet across all opportunities.

2. Initial /f/ at word and simple phrase level
- Practiced /f/ words (“fish, four, fun, feet, food”) using a fishing game and snack-themed pictures.
- Accuracy at the imitated word level increased compared to last session, with more reliable use of lip-biting and airflow.
- Introduced simple 2-word phrases (e.g., “four fish,” “fun food,” “big feet”). Child was able to maintain /f/ at the start of some words with verbal reminders, but still occasionally substituted /p/, particularly when speaking quickly.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued focus on isolation /s/ with mirror and visual supports. Child produced several clear /s/ sounds in a row with clinician modeling.
- Practiced CV syllables (“see, soo, say”) with variable accuracy. Some productions were closer to target /s/, while others shifted to /sh/ or /t/. Child showed increased awareness of tongue position and was willing to adjust after feedback.

4. Functional phrase length and intelligibility in play
- During spontaneous play, child used 3–4 word utterances (e.g., “I want the big car,” “my turn now”). Overall intelligibility was slightly improved compared to earlier sessions when talking about practiced /k/ and /f/ words, though speech remained less clear in unpracticed vocabulary.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue focusing on /k/ in short sentences and structured play, encouraging more spontaneous use of practiced /k/ words.
- Maintain /f/ practice at the word level with ongoing introduction of simple phrases; continue to support accurate lip and airflow patterns.
- Keep building consistency for /s/ in isolation and simple syllables; word-level /s/ will remain limited to probes.
- Caregiver encouraged to notice and praise spontaneous clear /k/ and /f/ productions at home and to model short, slow sentences containing these targets.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that the child is “really trying” to fix sounds and sometimes asks, “Was that right?” They are hearing more clear /k/ in words like “car” and “cookie” without reminders, and a few clearer /f/ words. No concerns about hearing or health.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered eagerly and requested specific toys. Demonstrated strong engagement with both play-based and structured tasks. Tolerated slightly longer practice sets and responded well to specific praise for effort and accuracy.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in sentences and early conversational contexts
- Continued practice with short sentences containing /k/ (e.g., “I see a cookie,” “The car is red,” “The cat is sleeping”).
- Compared to last week, child needed fewer direct cues and often produced /k/ correctly in the first attempt during imitation.
- In semi-structured conversation about favorite foods and toys, child produced several /k/ words with a clear back sound without being prompted (e.g., “cookie,” “cake,” “car”). These spontaneous productions represented a noticeable increase in independence.

2. Initial /f/ at word and 2–3 word phrase levels
- Practiced /f/ words and short phrases (“four fish,” “fun food,” “big feet,” “find it”) in a game format.
- Accuracy at the imitated word level continued to improve, and the child required fewer reminders to bite the lip.
- Phrases were more successful today, with more consistent /f/ in at least one of the target words per phrase. Occasional /p/ substitutions persisted, especially when excited, but the child frequently attempted to self-correct after feedback.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation, CV syllables, and limited word probes
- Child demonstrated more stable /s/ in isolation, able to hold a “long snake sound” for several seconds with correct tongue placement.
- CV syllables (“see, soo, say, suh”) were more accurate than previous sessions, though some productions still shifted to /sh/.
- Briefly probed initial /s/ words (“sun, sock, soup, sit”) at the imitated level. Several approximations were close to target /s/, indicating readiness to begin more consistent word-level practice soon.

4. Overall intelligibility in structured play
- In play-based tasks, child used 3–5 word utterances. Intelligibility within familiar topics (cars, animals, food) showed a modest but noticeable improvement, particularly when target sounds /k/ and /f/ were involved.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to reinforce /k/ in short sentences and expand to more natural conversation about familiar routines.
- Maintain /f/ practice at the word and phrase levels, with gradual fading of cues as accuracy stabilizes.
- Begin to increase focus on initial /s/ words in imitation next session while still supporting solid isolation skills.
- Caregiver encouraged to give specific feedback at home (e.g., “I heard your good back /k/ in ‘cookie’!”) and to keep modeling clear, slow speech during shared activities.

Parent report:
- Caregiver excitedly reported that relatives commented on the child being easier to understand this week. They notice clearer /k/ in many practiced words and some clearer /f/ in everyday speech. Caregiver is interested in working more on /s/ now that /k/ seems stronger.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child arrived in good spirits and transitioned quickly. Very engaged with a board game and pretend restaurant play. Demonstrated increased tolerance for corrective feedback and actively asked, “Did I do it?” after some attempts.

Goals / session focus:
1. Initial /k/ in spontaneous sentences and conversation
- Shifted focus from primarily imitated sentences to more natural, child-led conversation involving /k/ words (e.g., talking about cookies, cake, cars, and “going to the park”).
- Child produced many /k/ initial words accurately in spontaneous sentences with minimal or no cueing. Occasional fronting to /t/ occurred, but the child often self-corrected after a brief look from the clinician or a gentle reminder.
- Given the high level of independence and consistency observed today, /k/ is approaching conversational-level generalization for a core set of familiar words.

2. Initial /f/ in short sentences and structured conversation
- Expanded /f/ practice to short sentences (e.g., “Four fish swim,” “I see food,” “My feet are big”) during a fishing and restaurant game.
- Compared to previous sessions, child maintained /f/ more consistently across both words and short phrases, with fewer /p/ substitutions.
- In semi-structured conversation about favorite foods and family, several spontaneous /f/ words were produced with clearer lip posture (e.g., “five,” “food,” “four”). Some errors remained, but overall independence improved.

3. Initial /s/ at word level (imitation) with continued isolation practice
- Built on improved isolation skills to target initial /s/ words (“sun, sock, soup, seat, soap”) at the imitated word level.
- Child was able to produce several clear /s/ initial words when given a model and reminder to “keep tongue behind teeth.” Accuracy was higher than during earlier probes and improved over the course of the activity.
- Continued brief isolation practice between word trials to reset tongue placement, which helped maintain accuracy.

4. Functional intelligibility and self-monitoring
- Child used 3–5 word sentences in play (e.g., “My car goes fast,” “I want four cookies”).
- Intelligibility with the clinician was noticeably better, particularly for practiced vocabulary, and the child showed emerging self-monitoring (asking if productions were correct and attempting repairs).

Plan / recommendations:
- Begin to consider reducing direct focus on /k/ in structured drills, shifting more practice into conversational and carryover tasks.
- Continue to solidify /f/ at sentence level and encourage more spontaneous use in everyday topics.
- Increase emphasis on initial /s/ at the imitated word level, while continuing brief isolation practice as needed.
- Caregiver encouraged to incorporate “sound hunts” at home (e.g., looking for /s/ items like “sock, soap”) and to continue praising clear /k/ and /f/ productions in daily routines.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that the child is talking a lot at home and is easier to understand in familiar routines. They are starting to notice some better /s/ words, like “sun” and “sock,” but say it is not yet consistent. No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly and remained engaged in both table-top and floor-based activities. Participated well in turn-taking games, though required occasional prompts to slow down speech when excited.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ maintenance in conversational speech
- /k/ was monitored rather than directly drilled. During free play and conversation, child frequently used /k/ initial words accurately (e.g., “car,” “cookie,” “coat,” “cup”) with no explicit cueing.
- Occasional fronting to /t/ still occurred, but the child often corrected spontaneously or responded quickly to a light reminder.
- Overall, /k/ skills appeared stable at this higher level of the hierarchy.

2. Initial /f/ in short sentences and structured play
- Continued practice with /f/ in short sentences and simple games (e.g., “Four fish jump,” “My feet are cold,” “I found food”).
- Accuracy was generally similar to the previous session, with good success when the child watched the clinician’s model and slowed down.
- Some inconsistency remained in faster, more excited speech, but there were multiple clear productions across the session.

3. Initial /s/ at the imitated word level
- Focused on a small set of initial /s/ words (“sun, sock, soup, seat, soap, sand”).
- Child produced several accurate /s/ words in imitation when given verbal and visual cues. However, performance fluctuated with fatigue and attention.
- Isolation /s/ practice between trials continued to support correct tongue position, and the child showed a bit more stability compared to earlier sessions, though not a large jump.

4. Overall intelligibility and phrase length
- Child used 3–6 word sentences in structured play. Intelligibility with the clinician remained improved for practiced sounds and topics, with occasional breakdowns on less familiar words.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to monitor /k/ in conversation while shifting more direct practice time to /f/ and /s/.
- Maintain current level of challenge for /f/ (short sentences and structured play), focusing on consistency rather than increasing difficulty this week.
- Continue initial /s/ word-level work in imitation, aiming to gradually increase consistency before moving into phrases.
- Caregiver encouraged to keep modeling clear /s/ in everyday words (e.g., “soap, sun, cereal”) and to give positive feedback when the child produces a good /s/.

Parent report:
- Caregiver stated that speech has been “about the same” as last week. They still hear good /k/ in many words and some clearer /f/ and /s/, but it varies depending on the day and the child’s mood.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child arrived cheerful and cooperative. Attention and participation were similar to the previous session, with good engagement in play-based tasks and mild restlessness during longer drill activities.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in conversational speech (maintenance)
- /k/ continued to be monitored informally. Child produced many /k/ initial words accurately in conversation about cars, animals, and food.
- Occasional fronting persisted, but overall performance was stable compared to last week. No new difficulty observed.

2. Initial /f/ in sentences and structured play
- Practiced /f/ in short sentences (e.g., “Four fish swim,” “I feed the fish,” “My feet are wet”) using a fishing game.
- Accuracy and cueing needs were similar to the prior session. Child produced several clear /f/ initial words and phrases with moderate support.
- Substitutions to /p/ occurred, particularly when the child spoke quickly or was less attentive to the mouth posture. No major change in overall pattern.

3. Initial /s/ at imitated word level and emerging phrases
- Continued work on initial /s/ words (“sun, sock, soup, seat, sand”) in imitation.
- Accuracy at the word level was comparable to the previous session: some clear productions with cues, interspersed with /t/ and /sh/ substitutions.
- Briefly trialed 2-word phrases (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on”) in imitation. Child could sometimes maintain /s/ in the first word, but this remained challenging and required strong cueing.

4. Overall intelligibility
- Child used 3–6 word utterances in play. Intelligibility for the clinician remained similar to last week, with better clarity for practiced /k/ words and variable accuracy for /f/ and /s/.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue with current targets and difficulty levels for /f/ and /s/, as skills appear to be consolidating.
- Maintain /k/ at a conversational monitoring level with occasional reminders as needed.
- Caregiver encouraged to keep home practice light and positive, focusing on a few target words for /f/ and /s/ rather than many new words.

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that there were no big changes in speech this week. They still notice good /k/ and some clearer /f/ and /s/ words, but it “depends on how fast” the child is talking.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned well and participated in both floor play and table activities. Engagement, attention, and response to feedback were similar to the previous session.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in conversational speech (maintenance)
- /k/ remained strong in spontaneous speech for a variety of familiar words (e.g., “car, cookie, cake, coat”).
- Occasional fronting was observed, but overall performance mirrored last week’s stability. No new hierarchy changes were introduced.

2. Initial /f/ in sentences and structured play
- Continued practice of /f/ in short sentences and play (e.g., “Four fish jump,” “I feed the fish,” “My feet are cold”).
- Accuracy and need for cueing were consistent with prior sessions. Child produced multiple clear /f/ words with support but still showed /p/ substitutions, especially when speaking quickly or when less focused.

3. Initial /s/ in imitated words and simple phrases
- Targeted the same set of initial /s/ words as last week with imitation and visual/tactile cues.
- Child’s accuracy was similar to previous performance: some clear /s/ words when well-cued, alternating with /t/ or /sh/ productions.
- Practiced short 2-word phrases (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on”) in imitation; child was able to maintain /s/ in a portion of trials but still required substantial support.

4. Overall intelligibility
- Child continued to use 3–6 word utterances in structured play. Intelligibility for the clinician remained steady, with clearer speech for practiced /k/ words and variable clarity for /f/ and /s/.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain current goals and difficulty levels for /f/ and /s/ to allow further consolidation before increasing complexity.
- Continue informal monitoring of /k/ in conversation.
- Caregiver encouraged to continue brief, play-based practice of a few key /f/ and /s/ words each day, focusing on slow, clear speech and positive reinforcement.

Parent report:
- Caregiver indicated that the week was “about the same” for speech. They continue to hear strong /k/ and some improved /f/ and /s/, but consistency is still a work in progress. No additional concerns were raised.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child entered willingly and engaged in a similar manner to prior sessions. Attention and participation were steady, with good responsiveness to visual supports and praise.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in conversational speech (maintenance)
- /k/ production in spontaneous conversation remained stable and generally accurate across a range of familiar words.
- Occasional fronting persisted but was infrequent. No additional hierarchical changes were needed this week.

2. Initial /f/ in short sentences and structured conversation
- Continued practice using sentence frames and play (e.g., “I found four fish,” “My feet are dirty,” “I want food”).
- Child’s performance was similar to previous sessions: able to produce several clear /f/ initial words with visual and verbal cues, with ongoing substitutions to /p/ when less attentive.

3. Initial /s/ in imitated words and short phrases
- Practiced initial /s/ words and 2-word phrases (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on,” “soap bubbles”) in imitation.
- Accuracy remained variable but comparable to prior weeks. Child produced some clear /s/ with support, but still required frequent reminders for tongue placement and airflow.

4. Overall intelligibility and self-awareness
- Child continued to use multi-word utterances with similar intelligibility to last week. They occasionally asked if their sounds were “right,” showing ongoing self-awareness.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to reinforce and monitor /k/ in conversation.
- Maintain current practice level for /f/ and /s/, focusing on consistency and confidence rather than advancing task complexity this week.
- Caregiver encouraged to keep practice playful and to highlight moments when the child uses particularly clear /f/ or /s/ words (e.g., “I heard a great /s/ in ‘sock’!”).

Parent report:
- Caregiver reported that speech “feels pretty steady” compared to the last few weeks. They are pleased with how clear /k/ has become and note gradual, but not dramatic, changes for /f/ and /s/.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child arrived in a positive mood and participated well in familiar routines and games. Attention, cooperation, and response to feedback were consistent with recent sessions.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in conversational speech (maintenance)
- /k/ remained strong and generally accurate across spontaneous conversation. The child used many /k/ initial words (e.g., “cookie, car, cake, coat”) clearly without direct cueing.
- Occasional fronting was rare and typically self-corrected with minimal support.

2. Initial /f/ in sentences and structured play
- Practiced /f/ initial words and short sentences in games and picture description (e.g., “Four frogs jump,” “I feed the fish,” “My feet are wet”).
- Performance was comparable to prior weeks: several accurate /f/ productions with visual/verbal cues, interspersed with /p/ substitutions, particularly during faster or less structured speech.

3. Initial /s/ in imitated words and simple phrases
- Continued focus on initial /s/ words and short phrases in imitation (e.g., “sun up,” “sock on,” “soap bubbles”).
- Accuracy and cueing needs remained similar to previous sessions. Child produced some clear /s/ words when attention was high, but consistency across trials is still developing.

4. Overall intelligibility and summary of block
- In structured play and conversation, child’s intelligibility is noticeably better than at the start of the block, particularly for /k/ initial words and, to a lesser extent, for /f/.
- /k/ has largely generalized to conversational speech for a functional set of words, while /f/ and /s/ are showing emerging but inconsistent improvements.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to monitor /k/ in conversation in future sessions, with less direct drill needed unless regression is observed.
- Ongoing focus on /f/ and /s/ at the current complexity level, aiming for greater consistency before moving into more spontaneous and phrase-level /s/ work.
- Caregiver encouraged to maintain short, daily practice focusing on a few target /f/ and /s/ words, to praise self-corrections, and to model slow, clear speech during shared activities.
- Consider re-evaluating goal hierarchy in upcoming block to reflect strong /k/ progress and continued needs for /f/ and /s/.

Session 1

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother attended session and reported that she and father are understanding most of child's speech at home, but extended family and daycare staff often ask for repetition.
- She noted that he is especially hard to understand when he is excited or talking quickly.
- No concerns regarding hearing or recent illnesses.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned into the therapy room with some initial hesitation but separated from mother with verbal reassurance.
- Once engaged with toys, he was cheerful and talkative, though speech was often unintelligible in connected play.
- Attention to therapist-led tasks was fair; needed frequent redirection back to table activities from free play.

Therapy Goals & Observations:
Goal 1: Establish baseline for consonant production
- Informal speech sound inventory completed during play and picture naming.
- Noted consistent difficulty with: /k, g/ (often fronted to /t, d/), /s/ and /s/ blends (often omitted or substituted with /t/), and /sh/ (often produced as /s/).
- Final consonant deletion observed for /t, k, p/ in short words (e.g., "ca" for "cat").

Goal 2: Initial /k/ at syllable and simple word level (imitation)
- Practiced CV and VC syllables ("ku, ki, ak, ik") with visual cue of "back sound" and mirror.
- Child could approximate /k/ in isolation with maximal verbal and visual cues about 3–4 times; otherwise reverted to /t/.
- In simple words ("car, key, cow"), /k/ was produced accurately only with simultaneous production with SLP and strong cues; otherwise fronting persisted.

Goal 3: Initial /s/ in isolation and simple syllables

Plan/Recommendations:

- Home practice: parent encouraged to model slow, clear productions of target words ("car, key, pop") without pressure for imitation; praise any attempts at "back sounds" and final sounds.

Session 1

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Mother reported that intelligibility is "hit or miss" at home, especially when her child is excited. She notices many words without ending sounds and difficulty with /s/ and /f/ in everyday speech. No recent changes in health or hearing.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned into the therapy room with some hesitation but joined play after a brief warm-up. Generally cooperative with turn-taking games. Attention was best during highly motivating toy activities; needed occasional redirection when tasks became more structured.

Goals / Therapy Activities:
1. Establish accurate production of /f/ in isolation
   - Introduced /f/ as the "lip-bite, quiet air" sound using mirror and visual cueing. Child was able to approximate /f/ in isolation with maximal verbal and visual prompts. Accuracy was inconsistent; often substituted /p/ or used a prolonged /h/ instead of continuous airflow. Able to achieve a few clear /f/ productions when slowed down and reminded to "bite lip, blow."

2. Initial /f/ in CV and VC syllables (e.g., "fa," "foo," "if")
   - At the imitated syllable level, child required direct models and repeated practice. Productions frequently reduced to /p/ or omitted the consonant. A few accurate productions were observed when pairing with hand cues for airflow. Not yet ready to move to word-level without significant support.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and simple CV syllables
   - Modeled /s/ as the "snake sound" with tongue placement cues. Child could sometimes generate a prolonged /s/ in isolation with maximal support, but often produced /t/ or /sh/ instead. In CV syllables, consonant was usually omitted or distorted. Tolerated tactile and gestural cueing around the mouth.

4. Final consonant awareness in CVC words during play
   - Used picture cards and toys to highlight final sounds in high-interest words (e.g., "cup," "dog," "bus"). Child frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous speech. With imitation and focused listening tasks, could sometimes add a final /p/ or /m/, though productions were not yet consistent.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue to focus on establishing consistent /f/ and /s/ in isolation and simple syllables before advancing to word level.
- Encourage parent to model slow, clear productions at home and to highlight /f/ and /s/ sounds in familiar words (e.g., "fish," "sun") without asking for repeated corrections.
- Next session will revisit /f/ and /s/ isolation and CV/VC syllables, and continue to monitor final consonant production in play.

Goals / Therapy Activities:
1. /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
   - Notable improvement from last week. Child produced /f/ in isolation with moderate verbal and visual cues in most attempts. Fewer substitutions of /p/. In CV syllables ("fee," "fo," "fa"), accuracy was higher with slow modeling; child could imitate several clear productions in a row before fatigue. Still needed reminders to maintain airflow.

2. Initial /f/ in single words (imitation)
   - Trialed simple words (e.g., "fish," "fan," "foot") at the imitated word level. Child achieved some accurate productions, though consistency was variable. Tended to revert to /p/ when speaking more quickly ("pish" for "fish"). With segmenting and backward chaining (e.g., "ish" → "fish"), could correct with support. Emerging readiness to work at word level.

3. /s/ in isolation and simple syllables
   - Continued work on tongue placement using mirror and "snake sound" visual. Child showed more frequent successful /s/ productions in isolation with moderate cueing. In CV syllables ("see," "soo"), still some distortion but fewer /t/ substitutions. Required cues to keep tongue behind teeth.

4. Final consonant production in CVC words (imitation)
   - Practiced final /p, m, t/ in simple CVC words ("cup," "mom," "hat") using picture cards. Child imitated several final consonants when directly prompted, with improved awareness compared to last week. Omission remained common in spontaneous play, but attempts to add endings were observed when cued.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue to strengthen /f/ production at the word level with imitation, while maintaining isolation and syllable practice for carryover.
- Maintain focus on /s/ isolation and CV syllables before moving to consistent word-level practice.
- Encourage parent to play short "sound games" at home (e.g., finding objects that start with /f/) and to praise attempts rather than perfection.

- Able to maintain correct production over short series of trials (3–4 words in a row) with a simple verbal reminder to "make the snake sound" at the start.

2. Initial /s/ in simple carrier phrases (imitation)
- Introduced short phrases such as "my ___," "see ___" using /s/ words (e.g., "see sun," "my sock").
- Child could imitate several phrases with acceptable /s/ production when given a model. Accuracy decreased without a model, but this represents a step up in the hierarchy.

3. /f/ in isolation and initial CV syllables
- Continued practice with mirror and visual cue. Child produced /f/ in isolation with moderate cueing and showed less reliance on tactile support.
- Practiced CV syllables ("fee, foo, fah, fuh") in imitation. Accuracy was variable but improved compared to last week; more consistent frication and fewer /p/ substitutions.

4. General speech intelligibility
- In spontaneous play, the child’s short phrases were often understandable with context. Sound substitutions persisted, but listener understanding appeared slightly improved when the child slowed down.

Plan / recommendations:
- Begin to incorporate more phrase-level practice for initial /s/ while continuing to reinforce accuracy at the word level.
- Maintain focus on /f/ at isolation and simple syllable levels until accuracy is more stable.
- Home program: caregiver to practice a small set of /s/ words in short phrases (e.g., "see sun," "see sock") using a slow, playful model and plenty of praise.

Session 1

Parent/caregiver report:
- Parent shared that they are most concerned about others not understanding child’s speech, especially with new people. Reported that child often leaves off ending sounds and that “s” and “f” are hard to understand. No recent changes in health or hearing.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned with mild hesitation but separated from caregiver with support. Once in the room, engaged well with play-based tasks. Attention span was brief and required frequent redirection, but child was generally cheerful and willing to attempt imitation when given clear models.

Goals / therapy activities:
1) Establish production of early developing consonants in isolation and simple syllables (focus on /p, b, m, t, d/)
- Practiced CV and VC shapes (e.g., “pa,” “bee,” “me,” “up,” “eat”) in play with cars and animals.
- Child could imitate /p, b, m/ in CV syllables with moderate verbal and visual cueing; accuracy was inconsistent and often reduced to open vowels.
- Final consonants were usually omitted even with direct models (e.g., “up” → “uh,” “eat” → “ee”).

2) Introduce awareness of final consonants in simple words
- Used picture cards and a “quiet sound at the end” game (e.g., up, in, out, home).
- Child occasionally produced a final consonant with heavy modeling and simultaneous production but was not yet able to do so independently.
- Noted some awareness when SLP exaggerated final sound; child sometimes smiled and attempted to copy, but accuracy remained low.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Introduced /f/ using mirror, “bite lip, blow air” cue, and visual model.
- Child could blow air but often did not maintain lip placement; productions frequently approximated /h/ or were silent airflow.
- Very few clear /f/ productions despite maximal verbal, visual, and tactile cueing.

4) Initial /s/ in isolation
- Briefly probed /s/ with snake toy and mirror.
- Child tended to substitute /t/ or /d/ for /s/ in attempts, with difficulty maintaining a long “hissy” sound.
- Able to produce a short, inconsistent /s/-like sound when SLP provided hand cue and slowed rate, but this was not yet reliable.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build consistency for early consonants and increase awareness of final sounds.
- Maintain focus on /f/ and /s/ at isolation and simple syllable level with high support.
- Parent encouraged to model clear final sounds in everyday words (e.g., up, in, out) without asking child to repeat yet, just to increase exposure.
- Next session: re-check /p, b, m, t, d/ in simple syllables; continue shaping /f/ and /s/ in isolation.

Session 2

Parent/caregiver report:
- Parent noted no major changes since last week. Reported that child is “trying to copy more words” but is still hard to understand, especially at the end of words. No concerns with hearing or behaviour at home.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child came into therapy room more easily today and warmed up quickly with toys. Participated well in structured turn-taking games. Some impulsivity and talking over the clinician, but generally cooperative. Took short breaks between tasks and returned with light prompting.

Goals / therapy activities:
1) Early consonants in CV/VC syllables (/p, b, m, t, d/)
- Repeated practice with picture cards and a pretend picnic activity.
- Child imitated CV forms (e.g., “bee,” “tea,” “moo”) with increased consistency compared to last session; accuracy for initial consonants was generally good in imitation when focused.
- VC forms (e.g., “up,” “eat,” “in”) remained more challenging, but child produced several clearer final consonants with simultaneous production.

2) Final consonant awareness and production in simple words
- Used a “put the sound on” game with minimal pairs (e.g., “bee/beep,” “tea/teeth” where appropriate for age).
- Child produced a few accurate final consonants in imitation (e.g., “up,” “in”) with maximal verbal cueing and visual emphasis on the last sound.
- Still frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous attempts, but showed more frequent attempts to “add something at the end” when reminded.

3) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued mirror work with “bite lip, blow” cue, using a feather to visualize airflow.
- Child produced several approximations that were closer to /f/ today; still often reverted to /h/ or labial closure, but there were more clear fricative sounds than last week.
- Needed consistent modeling and reminders; no independent /f/ yet, but emerging awareness.

4) Initial /s/ in isolation and simple CV syllables
- Practiced /s/ with a toy snake and train, emphasizing “long, quiet snake sound.”
- Child could hold a short /s/-like sound in imitation more often than last session, though productions were brief and sometimes stopped to /t/.
- Able to imitate a few CV syllables (e.g., “see,” “soo”) with partial accuracy when watching SLP’s mouth.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue current targets as child is beginning to show emerging improvements, especially with early consonants and attempts at final sounds.
- Parent encouraged to play simple “sound on/off” games at home (e.g., “up” vs. “uh”) with exaggerated models, no pressure for perfect copying.
- Next session: continue building final consonants at VC level, and consolidate /f/ and /s/ in isolation before moving to more complex syllables.

Goals / therapy activities:

- Focused on VC items (e.g., up, in, out, eat) using picture cards and a “feed the animal” game where the animal only “ate” the word with the ending sound.

- Still needed support to carry this over to spontaneous attempts, but accuracy within structured imitation tasks showed a small increase.

2) Initial /f/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Continued mirror practice and lip-biting cues, paired with blowing cotton balls.
- Child produced several clear /f/ sounds in isolation when watching the clinician and following step-by-step instructions.
- Began to imitate a few CV syllables (e.g., “fee,” “fo”) with approximate /f/ at the start. Still inconsistent, but more frequent successful attempts compared to last week.

3) Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Used “snake sound” in a board game, requiring /s/ productions to move pieces.
- Child’s ability to sustain a short /s/ in imitation is emerging; more attempts were audible and closer to target.
- Imitated several CV syllables (e.g., “see,” “soo,” “suh”) with partial accuracy; substitutions (/t/ or /d/) still occurred but slightly less often.

4) Early consonant CV syllables in play
- Practiced /p, b, m, t, d/ in simple CV words within play (e.g., “bee,” “moo,” “tea,” “do”).
- Child maintained fairly good initial consonant accuracy during imitation tasks, though some omissions occurred as play became faster or more spontaneous.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain focus on final consonants at VC level and continue building consistency before moving to full CVC words.
- Continue shaping /f/ and /s/ in CV syllables; accuracy is slowly increasing but not yet stable enough to move up a level.
- Parent encouraged to highlight final consonants in a few routine words (e.g., up, in, out) and to praise any attempts at “end sounds.”
- Next session: re-check VC and simple CVC forms; continue /f/ and /s/ CV practice in play.

Parent report:

Behavior/engagement:

Goals / Observations:
1. Final consonant production in CVC words and carrier phrases
- Targeted final /p, t, m, n/ across familiar and a few new CVC words and phrases.
- Maintained strong accuracy at imitated word level with minimal cues.
- In phrases, performance was stable: consistent marking of final consonants in shorter, rehearsed phrases, with more frequent omissions in less familiar or longer phrases.

2. Initial /k/ in words and two-word phrases
- Continued work on initial /k/ in words and two-word phrases.
- Demonstrated ongoing stable performance with frequent correct productions and occasional fronting that corrected with simple cues.

3. Initial /s/ in words and short phrases
- Practiced initial /s/ in isolation and a familiar word set, with some attempts at phrases.
- Isolation /s/ remained reliable. Word-level accuracy was similar to prior sessions, with some clear productions and some substitutions.
- Phrases required maximal support, with no significant change in independence.

4. Intelligibility in play
- In spontaneous conversation and play, speech remained moderately unintelligible to an unfamiliar listener, though familiar listeners (clinician, caregiver) could understand more with context. Patterns of final consonant deletion and sound substitution were still evident.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue with current targets and levels to maintain and gradually strengthen skills.
- Encourage caregiver to highlight and praise any spontaneous correct productions of final consonants and /k/ words.
- Plan to reassess overall progress at the end of the block and determine whether to adjust goals or approaches.

Parent report:

Behavior/engagement:

Goals / Observations:

- Accuracy continued to be generally good, with occasional fronting that was quickly corrected.
- No notable change in overall performance from previous sessions.

3. Initial /s/ in words and supported phrases
- Continued to work on initial /s/ in isolation and words; attempted some simple phrases with maximal support.
- Isolation /s/ remained a strength; word-level accuracy was similar to recent sessions.
- Phrase-level productions were still inconsistent and heavily cue-dependent.

Goals / Observations:

- In carrier phrases, performance remained similar to recent sessions: good accuracy in short, practiced phrases; increased omissions in longer or more spontaneous utterances. Skills appear stable at this level.

- Probed initial /k/ in a range of words and two-word phrases.

3. Initial /s/ in words and supported phrases

Session 1

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that she understands most of child's speech but others often have difficulty, especially with longer words and when he talks quickly.
- No concerns about hearing. Child starting preschool in the fall.
- Mom notices he often leaves off the ends of words and says “do” for “go,” “tat” for “cat.”

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned to the therapy room with some initial hesitation but separated from caregiver with reassurance.
- Once engaged in play, he was cheerful and interactive, though easily distracted by new toys and needed intermittent redirection to speech tasks.
- Responded well to visual supports and turn-taking games.

Goals / observations:
1. Establish baseline for speech sound production
- Informal play-based speech sample revealed frequent final consonant deletion (e.g., “ca” for “cat,” “bee” for “beep”), and some initial sound substitutions (/t/ for /k/, /d/ for /g/; occasional /p/ for /f/).
- Syllable shapes observed included CV, CVCV (same and alternating), and some CVC words, often missing final consonants.
- Intelligibility judged to be fair in context with familiar listener (SLP) but reduced for out-of-context phrases.

2. Initial /k/ and /g/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Child was able to imitate /k/ in isolation inconsistently with visual cue to “tap tongue at the back” and model; often reverted to /t/.
- /g/ in isolation was more difficult; most attempts approximated /d/.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “koo,” “kah”), child needed maximal verbal and visual cueing and simultaneous production; only a few clear productions noted.

3. Final consonant production (awareness and imitation)
- Introduced concept of “sound at the end” using minimal pairs and picture cards (e.g., “bee/beep,” “bow/boat”).
- With direct imitation and emphasis on the final consonant, child could sometimes add final /p/ or /t/ but consistency was low; required frequent modeling and slowed rate.
- Tended to add a neutral vowel after final consonants (e.g., “cat-uh”).

4. Early /f/ in initial position (emerging awareness)
- Briefly probed initial /f/ in single words (fish, fun, five) using “bite lip and blow” visual cue.
- Child often substituted /p/ or omitted the fricative component; one or two close approximations with hand cue for airflow.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue to build rapport and play-based participation while targeting initial /k, g/ in isolation and CV syllables, and final consonant production for /p, t/.
- Encourage parent to model slow, clear speech at home and highlight final sounds in daily routines (e.g., “up,” “bed,” “cup”).
- Provide parent with simple picture cards to practice 5 short CVC words with final /p/ once per day, focusing on listening and imitation rather than perfection.

Session 2

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported no major changes since last visit.
- She tried some of the CVC word practice; child was willing but often “got silly” and left off the end sounds.
- She continues to notice difficulty with “k” sounds, especially at the start of words.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child separated easily from caregiver and entered the room willingly.
- Very active and curious; needed frequent reminders to sit or stay with the activity but responded well to short, game-like tasks.
- Enjoyed using a mirror and watching the SLP’s mouth.

Goals / observations:
1. Initial /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- With visual model, mirror, and “cough” trick, child produced /k/ in isolation more reliably than last session, though still inconsistent.
- In CV syllables (e.g., “koo,” “kah,” “kee”), child achieved several clear productions with simultaneous production and verbal cueing; still reverted to /t/ without cues.
- Tolerated tactile/gestural cue (pointing to throat) and began to anticipate “back sound” when reminded.

2. Initial /g/ in isolation
- /g/ remained more challenging; continued to substitute /d/ frequently.
- A few approximations were heard when pairing sound with gross motor movement (e.g., jumping for “go”), but accuracy remained low and required maximal support.

3. Final /p/ and /t/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Practiced high-interest words (e.g., “cup,” “up,” “hot,” “hat”) using picture cards and toy reinforcers.
- With direct imitation and slowed rate, child produced some clear final /p/ and /t/, but often omitted final consonant when excited or speaking quickly.
- When cued to “tap the last sound,” he attempted to add a final consonant, even if not always accurate.

4. Syllable shape expansion (CVCV)
- Practiced simple CVCV words (e.g., “bunny,” “happy,” “cookie”) in play.
- Most syllables were present, though some consonants were distorted or simplified.
- Child enjoyed chanting and singing-style repetition, which supported increased participation.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue focusing on initial /k/ in isolation and simple CV syllables; maintain /g/ at isolation level only for now.
- Keep practicing a small set of CVC words with final /p, t/ at home, emphasizing listening for the “last sound.”
- Introduce a visual cue (e.g., tapping a picture edge) to mark the final sound for home practice.

Session 3

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother shared that child has started trying to copy her when she exaggerates the “k” in words like “car” and “cookie.”
- She feels he is a bit more aware of his “back sounds,” though accuracy is still inconsistent.
- No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child transitioned smoothly and appeared eager to show toys and talk.
- Attention to tasks improved compared to previous session; he stayed with table-top activities for longer stretches when they were game-based.
- Responded well to praise and was motivated by turn-taking with a favorite puzzle.

Goals / observations:
1. Initial /k/ at CV and simple word level (imitation)
- Child produced /k/ in isolation with good consistency when given a brief reminder.
- In CV syllables, accuracy improved; he was able to imitate “koo, kah, kee” with clearer back placement in many attempts.
- Introduced a small set of initial /k/ words (car, key, cow, cookie). With imitation and visual cue, he produced recognizable /k/ in the initial position in a meaningful portion of trials, though still occasional /t/ substitutions.

2. Initial /g/ in isolation and CV
- Continued practice of /g/ in isolation with visual and tactile cues; a few more accurate productions noted compared to last week, but still less consistent than /k/.
- CV syllables (e.g., “goo,” “gah”) were trialed; child could approximate these with heavy cueing but often reverted to /d/ when attention decreased.

3. Final /p/ and /t/ in CVC words (imitation)
- Practiced sets of CVC words using toys (e.g., feeding a “cup,” placing items in a “hat”).
- With slowed rate and direct modeling, child produced final /p/ and /t/ more frequently than in previous sessions; still omitted final consonants when excited or when moving to more spontaneous speech.
- Began to spontaneously attempt final consonants in a few unprompted words after hearing the model several times.

4. Early introduction of /f/ in initial position (imitation)
- Targeted /f/ in high-interest words (fish, fun, four) with “bite lip and blow” cue.
- Child was able to produce some recognizable /f/ sounds when looking in the mirror, though he still occasionally used /p/ or omitted the fricative portion.
- He appeared to enjoy the “blowing air” component and responded to visual airflow cues.

Plan/recommendations:
- Continue building accuracy for initial /k/ at the word level in imitation before moving to phrases.
- Maintain /g/ at isolation/CV level with strong support.
- Continue short home practice with a limited set of CVC words and 2–3 /k/ initial words (e.g., car, cookie, key), focusing on slow, clear productions.
- Encourage caregiver to praise attempts at “back sounds,” not just perfect productions.

2. Initial /g/ in isolation and CV syllables

- Still not ready to move to word-level /g/ without more stability.

3. Final /p/ and /t/ in CVC words (imitation to cued spontaneous)
- Continued practice with CVC words using play-based tasks (e.g., putting items “in cup,” talking about something being “hot”).

Plan/recommendations:

Session 1

Parent/Caregiver Report:
- Caregiver reported that child is "hard to understand" for unfamiliar listeners and often leaves off sounds at the ends of words.
- No previous speech therapy. Caregiver noted child will sometimes repeat words if asked but gets "silly" when corrected.

Behaviour/Engagement:
- Child transitioned into the therapy room with some hesitation but separated from caregiver with reassurance.
- Once settled, engaged well in play-based activities and responded to visual games and toys.
- Attention to adult-directed tasks was brief (2–3 minutes) and required frequent redirection from self-directed play.

Goals / Treatment Focus:
1. Establish awareness of final consonants (CVC words)
   - Used picture cards and simple toys to elicit CVC words (e.g., "cup," "bus," "bed").
   - Child frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous attempts (e.g., "bu" for "bus").
   - With direct imitation and visual cueing (touching mouth, pointing to final sound icon), child produced the final consonant in some trials, but productions were inconsistent and often reduced to a vowel-consonant blend.

2. Initial /k/ at syllable and simple word level (imitation)
   - Practiced /k/ in isolation using "back sound" cues (e.g., "tongue goes in the back").
   - Child was able to approximate /k/ in isolation in about half of attempts, with frequent substitution of /t/.
   - At syllable level ("koo," "kah") and in simple words ("car," "key"), productions were mostly /t/; occasional correct productions with simultaneous model and verbal cueing.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
   - Introduced /s/ as a "long, quiet snake sound" with visual model and mirror.
   - Child could prolong a "hissy" sound in isolation with heavy support, but there was frequent stopping or distortion.
   - Attempts in CV syllables ("see," "soo") were mostly reduced to /t/ or /d/; occasional closer approximations when watching clinician's mouth.

4. Baseline observation of overall speech sound patterns
   - In play-based conversation, child showed frequent final consonant deletion, fronting of /k/ and /g/ to /t/ and /d/, and variable vowel clarity.
   - Syllable shapes heard: V, CV, CVCV; CVC was emerging but inconsistent.

Plan / Recommendations:
- Continue to build awareness of final consonants and back sounds (/k/) at the imitation level.
- Use simple CVC words in play at home; caregiver to model and gently emphasize final sound (e.g., "cuP," "buS") without pressuring child to repeat.
- Next session: re-check /k/ and final consonants; consider introducing visual markers (tokens/picture cues) for beginning vs. ending sounds.

Needed some redirection away from preferred toys but responded to visual schedules and clear expectations. Participated in imitation tasks with good effort and responded well to specific praise.

Goals/activities:
1. Final consonant production (CVC words: /p, m, t/)
- Targeted simple CVC words (e.g., "map, mop, mat, up, cup, mom") at the imitated word level.
- Child frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous speech (e.g., "ma" for "map"), but with direct imitation and visual cueing (tapping for the last sound), produced clearer final consonants in some trials.
- Accuracy was inconsistent; often added a vowel after the final sound ("map-uh"). Continued to require models and reminders to "stop the sound at the end."

2. Initial /k/ vs /t/
- Practiced initial /k/ in simple words ("key, car, cow") using a "back sound" cue and mirror work.
- Child tended to substitute /t/ for /k/ (e.g., "tea" for "key") on first attempts.
- With maximal verbal and visual cueing (hand to throat, "tongue up and back"), was able to imitate /k/ in isolation in several attempts; carryover to words remained limited.

3. Initial /s/ in single words
- Introduced initial /s/ in isolation and then in a few single words ("sun, soup, sock").
- Child was able to approximate /s/ in isolation when given a "snake sound" cue and encouraged to keep the tongue behind the teeth.
- In words, productions were variable, with some substitutions (e.g., "dun" for "sun"). Required frequent models and visual cues.

Plan/recommendations:
Continue to focus on final consonant production in simple CVC words and establishing consistent /k/ and /s/ at the imitated word level. Parent was shown how to emphasize last sounds in everyday words (e.g., "up, in, out") and encouraged to model slow, clear speech without pressuring the child to repeat. Will reassess readiness to increase complexity once accuracy improves.

Parent report:
Mother reported that child is "copying more" at home and will sometimes repeat short words when prompted, but final sounds are still often missing. She has been trying the "tap the last sound" strategy and feels the child is starting to notice when words "have an ending."

Behaviour/engagement:
Child entered the room more easily today and quickly engaged with a car and animal set. Attention was generally good for short, structured tasks, with brief breaks for play. Showed good willingness to imitate and enjoyed listening for "silly" vs "right" words.

Goals/activities:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t/)
- Revisited CVC words at the imitated word level using picture cards and a simple board game.
- Child showed increased awareness of final sounds, often pausing and attempting to "add the end" after a model.
- Still inconsistent, but more frequent accurate productions of final /p/ and /m/ when provided with a visual cue (tapping or pointing to the final sound picture).

2. Initial /k/ in words
- Practiced /k/ in isolation and in initial position of simple words ("key, car, cow, cake").
- Child produced /k/ in isolation more consistently with a "cough"/"back sound" cue.
- At the word level, substitutions to /t/ still occurred, but there were several clear productions of "key" and "car" after a direct model. Needed moderate to maximal cueing but demonstrated more attempts and fewer refusals.

3. Initial /s/ in words and simple phrases
- Targeted initial /s/ in words ("sun, soup, sock, seat") using a "quiet snake" visual and mirror.
- Child was able to produce /s/ in isolation in most attempts with verbal reminders to "keep teeth together."
- At the word level, accuracy improved slightly compared to last session, with more consistent approximations. Still required frequent modeling; occasional substitution to /d/ or omission of the sound.

Plan/recommendations:
Continue current focus on final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/ at the imitated word level. Accuracy is beginning to emerge but is not yet consistent. Parent encouraged to play short listening games at home ("Do you hear the end in 'up'?") and to keep practice brief and fun. Will consider introducing simple carrier phrases once word-level productions become more reliable.

Parent report:
Mother shared that the child has been "trying to fix" words when she gives a gentle reminder, especially with words like "up" and "out." She feels speech is "a tiny bit clearer" with close family, though unfamiliar listeners still have difficulty. No new concerns.

Behaviour/engagement:
Child transitioned smoothly and appeared eager to show toys. Attention to table-top tasks improved; tolerated slightly longer practice sets when activities were embedded in games. Showed some self-monitoring, laughing when hearing "silly" productions.

Goals/activities:
1. Final consonants in CVC words (/p, m, t, k/)
- Practiced a larger set of CVC words ("map, mop, mat, cup, cut, back, book, mom") at the imitated word level and in short carrier phrases ("my ___").
- Child demonstrated noticeably better consistency with final /p/ and /m" in imitation, often producing the ending without an additional vowel.
- Final /t/ and /k/ remained more challenging, but there were several accurate attempts when given a visual cue (pointing to the final sound icon) and slowed rate.
- Able to maintain some final consonants within simple phrases (e.g., "my cup") with moderate cues.

2. Initial /k/ in words and CV syllables
- Continued work on initial /k/ using CV syllables ("ku, ki, ko") and simple words.
- Child produced /k/ in isolation with good success after initial cueing, needing fewer repetitions.
- In words, substitutions to /t/ decreased slightly; there were multiple clear productions of "key" and "cow" in imitation. Still needed verbal reminders about "back sound," but less physical prompting.

3. Initial /s/ in words and emerging phrases
- Targeted /s/ in initial position of familiar words ("sun, soup, sock, sand, seat") during a picture lotto game.
- Child produced /s/ in isolation consistently when given a brief model.
- At the word level, accuracy improved, with more consistent initial /s/ and fewer substitutions. Some attempts at two-word phrases ("see sun," "see sock") were made in imitation, with partial carryover of /s/.

Plan/recommendations:
Given the child’s increasing consistency with final consonants and initial /s/ and /k/ in imitation, we will continue to strengthen accuracy at the word level and gradually expand to more carrier phrases where appropriate. Parent was encouraged to model short two-word phrases highlighting final sounds (e.g., "big cup") and to praise any clear final consonants, even if the rest of the word is approximate.

Parent report:

Goals/activities:
1. Final consonants in CVC words and short carrier phrases (/p, m, t, k/)

- Child produced final /p/ and /m/ with good consistency in imitation and was beginning to include these sounds spontaneously within phrases during structured play.
- Final /t/ and /k/ showed noticeable gains; there were many accurate productions in imitation and some self-corrections when the child initially omitted the final sound.

2. Initial /k/ at word and carrier phrase level
- Targeted initial /k/ words ("key, car, cow, cookie, cat") in a picture guessing game.
- Child produced /k/ more reliably in words, with fewer /t/ substitutions. Needed mainly verbal cues rather than intensive visual/tactile prompts.
- Began to use initial /k/ within short imitated phrases ("my car," "big cookie") with moderate success.

3. Initial /s/ in words and two-word combinations
- Practiced /s/ in initial position ("sun, soap, sock, soup, seat") using a turn-taking game.
- Child maintained accurate /s/ in most imitated words and was ready to trial two-word phrases (e.g., "see sun," "soap here").
- Some spontaneous use of /s/ in simple phrases was observed in play (e.g., approximated "see sun" while looking at pictures) with minimal prompting.

Plan/recommendations:
Given the meaningful gains, we will continue to build complexity by using more carrier phrases and short two-word combinations, particularly for final consonants and initial /k/ and /s/. Parent was shown how to model phrases like "my cup" and "big sock" and to emphasize the target sounds in a natural way. Next sessions will focus on consolidating phrase-level accuracy and monitoring for any carryover into spontaneous play.

Goals/activities:

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that child is "trying more words" at home but is still hard to understand for unfamiliar listeners. No concerns about hearing. Family is motivated to work on clear speech.

Behaviour/engagement:
- 4-year-old child transitioned to the therapy room with brief hesitation but separated from caregiver with encouragement. Once in the room, engaged well with toys and accepted structured tasks. Attention was variable; needed intermittent redirection back to speech activities but responded to visual supports and play-based routines.

Goals / session focus:
1. Establish production of /k/ and /g/ in isolation
- Targeted back sounds /k/ and /g/ in isolation using mirrors, visuals, and play with cars and animals. Child frequently substituted /t/ and /d/ for /k/ and /g/ (e.g., saying "t" for /k/). With simultaneous productions and maximal verbal/visual cueing ("tongue back, coughing sound"), child produced approximations of /k/ in ~3–4 attempts per 10 trials. /g/ was more difficult; mostly produced /d/ despite repeated modeling. Able to briefly feel the "back of the tongue" with clinician hand-over-hand to touch throat area, but carryover to sound production was inconsistent.

2. Initial /s/ in isolation and simple syllables
- Introduced "long, quiet snake sound" /s/ in isolation. Child could imitate a prolonged /s/ in 4/10 attempts with strong visual cueing and clinician modeling. Productions were often too short or voiced (more like /z/). Trialed CV syllables ("see," "soo") in a few attempts; most responses were approximations with variable accuracy. Required direct imitation and maximal cues; no independent productions observed.

3. Final consonant awareness (CVC words)
- In play with picture cards (e.g., "bus," "cup," "cat"), child frequently omitted final consonants or reduced them to a weak vowel ("bu," "cu"). Clinician modeled clear final sounds and used tapping and segmenting. Child was able to imitate clearer final consonants in 2–3 opportunities per word with heavy support. No spontaneous final consonant productions in connected play.

4. Functional communication / phrase length observation
- During free play, child primarily used single words and short memorized phrases ("my turn," "I want"). Intelligibility in connected speech was reduced due to sound errors and omissions. Child attempted to repair breakdowns when not understood by repeating or pointing.

Plan / recommendations:
- Continue to build consistency for /k/ and /g/ in isolation before moving to syllables. Maintain focus on establishing a stable /s/ in isolation and simple CV syllables. Continue modeling final consonants in simple CVC words.
- Home program: caregiver to practice "coughing sound" /k/ in front of the mirror using fun car/animal pictures, aiming for a few short, positive practice bursts per day. Encourage slow, clear models at home without pressuring the child.

Parent/caregiver report:
- Mother reported that child is "copying sounds" at home more often and occasionally trying to say "car" with a clearer /k/ after being reminded. She feels speech is still mostly unclear but has noticed more attempts.

Behaviour/engagement:
- Child separated from caregiver with minimal hesitation today and eagerly joined play. Demonstrated good participation in structured games when activities were short and varied. Some impulsive talking over clinician, but easily redirected using visual cues and turn-taking routines.

Goals / session focus:
1. /k/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Reviewed /k/ in isolation. Compared to last session, child produced a clearer /k/ with clinician model in approximately half of the opportunities. Able to maintain tongue-back posture with verbal cue "back sound" and visual mirror support. Transitioned into simple CV syllables ("koo," "kah," "kee") during a car-racing game. In imitation, produced approximations in most trials, with several clearly recognizable /k/ syllables. Still needed frequent cues, but accuracy and confidence were notably improved from baseline.

2. /g/ in isolation
- Reintroduced /g/ using "frog sound" imagery. Child continued to prefer /d/, but there were a few clearer /g/ approximations during simultaneous productions. Some emerging awareness of the difference when clinician contrasted "do" vs. "go" with visual mouth cues. Accuracy remains low overall, but child is beginning to attempt /g/ more consistently.

3. Initial /s/ in isolation and CV syllables
- Practiced "snake sound" /s/ in isolation, then in "see/soo/suh" during a feeding-toys game. Compared to last session, child could hold a longer, quieter /s/ in more trials with visual support (finger to lips, snake picture). In imitation, produced /s/ in isolation correctly in approximately 6/10 attempts; CV syllables were less consistent but present in several recognizable productions. Still requires direct modeling and cueing but showing emerging control.

4. Final consonant production in CVC words (imitation)
- Continued to model final consonants in CVC words ("bus," "bed," "cup," "dog"). With imitation and segmenting/tapping cues, child produced clearer final sounds in more attempts than previous session, particularly for /p/ and /t/. Still frequently omitted final consonants in spontaneous play, but in structured drill, accuracy in imitation is beginning to increase.

Plan / recommendations:
- Maintain focus on /k/ CV syllables and begin to stabilize these before moving to word-level. Continue to elicit /s/ in isolation and CV syllables with visual supports. Ongoing emphasis on awareness of final consonants in CVC words.
- Home practice: encourage short practice of "back sound" /k/ in fun syllables ("koo," "kah") and "snake sound" /s/ in front of a mirror. Caregiver to emphasize listening and praise for attempts rather than perfection.
